title: SEVENTH NERVE DISORDERS: THE OPHTHALMIC PERSPECTIVE
summary: The facial nerve (VII) is critical to ophthalmology due to its role in eyelid closure via the orbicularis oculi. This poster outlines the anatomy, functions, clinical assessment, and management of facial nerve palsies, with a specific focus on Bell's palsy.

sections.title: Critical Warning for Ophthalmologists
content: Facial nerve palsy should not be underestimated.
Do NOT automatically assume that every facial nerve palsy is a ‘Bell’s palsy’.
Be alert to its capacity to cause BLINDING EXPOSURE KERATOPATHY (see Box 16.15).

The seventh or facial nerve has important motor, sensory, and secretory functions. Of these, the ability to close the eyelids (innervation of orbicularis oculi) makes it so important to the ophthalmologist.

sections.title: Anatomy Reference
sections.content: Anatomy: See E Anatomy and physiology (3), p. 732.

branches: Motor: Muscles of facial expression and movement
Motor: Superficial platysma muscles of the neck
Sensory/Secretory: Lacrimal gland (via greater superficial petrosal nerve)
Sensory/Secretory: Taste for anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Structures: Nervus intermedius and geniculate ganglion

sections.title: Clinical Features & Assessment
content: Weakness of one side of the face/ facial asymmetry (if unilateral).
Lagophthalmos, with or without lower lid ectropion.
NB Specifically assess: corneal sensation, tear film, signs of exposure keratopathy, lid closure, orbicularis strength, and Bell’s phenomenon.

sections.title: Differential: Isolated vs Complex?
content: 1. Check for involvement of all other cranial nerves.

rows: Upper facial muscles still function (e.g. can still raise eyebrows)
Due to bilateral innervation (see E Anatomy and physiology (3), p. 732).
Both upper and lower facial muscles are involved.
Complete paralysis of the ipsilateral side.

sections.title: Investigations for All Palsies
content: ENT or neurology referral to establish a cause for all new-onset facial nerve palsies.
Neuroimaging: Mandatory for all RECURRENT facial nerve palsy to exclude inflammatory or neoplastic causes.

sections.title: General Treatment Strategies
content: Lubricants: Intensive preservative-free artificial tears during the day.
Lid closure: Consider taping lid closed at night (temporary).
Tarsorrhaphy: Have a low threshold for performing a temporary tarsorrhaphy.
Chronic cases: Insertion of gold weights to the upper lid can be helpful.

sections.title: Box 16.15: Causes of VIIn Palsy
content: * Commonly present with bilateral VIIn weakness.

sections.title: Bell’s Palsy (Idiopathic Facial Paralysis)
sections.content: Although the majority of facial nerve palsy (up to 70%) are idiopathic, this is a diagnosis of exclusion. It can affect any age group (peak 40y), with ♂ and ♀ equally affected. Associations include diabetes and pregnancy. Symptoms reach their peak at 48h; most start recovery at 3wk. For investigations: Assess and investigate as for unexplained facial nerve palsy.

sections.title: Exposure & Late Stage Management
content: Exposure: Treat corneal exposure with lubricants and lid closure as needed (see E Exposure keratopathy, pp. 300–1).
Surgical Treatment (Late): Can improve function and cosmesis (facial nerve repair, nerve substitution, muscle transposition).
Crocodile Tears: Gustatory hyperlacrimation 2° to aberrant regeneration.
Treatment for Crocodile Tears: Transcutaneous injection of botulinum toxin to the lacrimal gland.
